title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) — The hardwood floor of the Spectrum belonged to one man, a force of nature clad in New York orange and blue. In a performance for the ages, Patrick Ewing delivered a titanic effort, pouring in a herculean 44 points to single-handedly carry the New York Knicks to a bruising 111-100 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

From the opening tip, this was the Ewing Show. The Knicks' center was an unstoppable force in the paint, his trademark turnaround jumper falling with metronomic consistency. He was the engine of the New York offense, and when the Sixers threatened to close the gap, Ewing had an answer—a powerful drop-step, a feathery touch from the baseline, or a commanding presence on the glass.

While Allan Houston provided a crucial 22-point supporting performance, this night was defined by one historic individual battle. Philadelphia’s Allen Iverson, the electrifying rookie, countered with a brilliant 37 points of his own, a dazzling display of speed and shot-making that lit up the home crowd. But for every acrobatic layup Iverson manufactured, Ewing responded with a demoralizing, fundamental bucket.

The game was a testament to Ewing’s will. In the crucible of a tight contest, the Knicks rode their legendary center, feeding him possession after possession. He shouldered the load without hesitation, dominating the interior and sealing the game from the foul line. His 44-point masterpiece was more than just a win; it was a statement—a legendary performance from a premier center at the absolute peak of his powers, forever etching this night in the annals of Knicks lore.
